text: [Music] I'm Phil bden I'm the agronomist with um pulse Agronomy Australia uh X pulse Australia and X DPI uh I specialize in Pest Management Farmers should be um monitoring um at the moment particularly for aphids The Usual Suspects of um green peach aphid and cabbage aphid uh we often see at this time of year and the one of most concern is green Peach aord because it's high chemical resistance and also the fact that it will transfer virus very quickly into into plants um in general though you know a lot of these aphids are pretty well controlled by a lot of the natural enemies yeah you should be seeing uh evidence of parasitism you know from the parasitic wasps uh you might see Lady Bole ly hoverfly ly and lacewing ly that are are um very capable of keeping uh those uh Apen pests in check uh if you're not seeing it though um well I guess you have to make a decision whether you need to spray uh the current recommendation uh would be for one of the soft chemicals um uh pamore transform um are the two that are are currently um used with with good effect they don't affect um uh the beneficial insects the with the latest canala varieties that are often very vigorous you those varieties can often outgrow damage but um yeah it's just a matter of uh monitoring regularly uh to see what's in the crop I mean that's I guess the basic principle of integrated Pest Management is out there monitoring regularly uh systematically so that you you know what's you know what you're dealing with in the crop grazing can have an effect on uh keeping pests in check but it's usually uh when the grazing pressure is very high yeah so you'll still have residual pest numbers after grazing so that's when it's important like to to just go and uh monitor regularly uh to um see what you're dealing with in in the field after grazing and then you know after grazing farmers are often top dressing so that's getting the crop off um to a um higher growth uh rate um as well that can help and you know with a lot of the current varieties that are very vigorous they will outgrow any damage so very rarely that at this time of year that we need to intervene with a chemical getting back to our basic principles of integrated Pest Management it's out there checking regularly monitoring that you uh so you know what you're dealing with then you can make decisions about whether there are um natural enemies there that are keeping it under control or whether you have to use a um a chemical um and or or other management um tool there are lots of resources available uh the most um high-profile one is probably PESA which is a uh a service that's offered by uh Caesar group from Melbourne University and that relies on uh farmers and agronomists uh sending them information whenever they see uh you know anomalies in crops or they they want identification done uh they have a very good service and that's usually you know taking a photo of any uh unusual occurrence they might see in a crop whether it's distorted leaves or you know signs or symptoms of the pests and they need it identified it can be done through pests or through local Land Services uh with um their um local uh agronomists and they will send it on to uh well Caesar or myself or someone to get it get it identified so there are resources there uh there's quite a bit of um uh written material there uh notes for example which is a GC uh resource on on on the website um and pulse Australia website is still active uh they can they can be used to uh help with um PES identification
